sur=1-n_sur

source.8d79c712: ### Considered to be an “unsinkable” ship, Titanic was the largest and most luxurious cruise liner of its day, measuring more than 882 feet long from prow to stern—the length of four-city blocks—and 175 feet high, and weighing more than 46,000 tons. It boasted state-of-the-art technology, including a sophisticated electrical control panel, four elevators and an advanced wireless communications system that could transmit Morse Code.Who did realise that the sail, would become one of the tragedic history in the world? Here we shall dig upon it's climax, predicting the survibality.

source.391b3442:
The above is our train data_set holding the following information :

1. PassengerId :  Specifies each passenger's ID
2. Survived    :  0 - Not Survived ; 1- Survived
3. Pclass      :  Passenger class : 1,2,3
4. Name        :  Name of the passenger
5. Sex         :  Gender
6. Age         :  Age
7. SibSp       :  Siblings/Spouse onboard
8. Parch       :  Parent/Child onboard
9. Ticket      :  Ticket No.
10. Fare       :  Fare
11. Cabin      :  Cabin No.
12. Embarked   :  Port of Embarkation (C = Cherbourg; Q = Queenstown; S = Southampton)

source.6b1eb704:
# Summary:

****The immediate cause of RMS Titanic’s demise was a collision with an iceberg that caused the ocean liner to sink on April 14–15, 1912. While the ship could reportedly stay afloat if as many as 4 of its 16 compartments were breached, the impact had affected at least 5 compartments. It was originally believed that the iceberg had caused a long gash in the hull. After examining the wreck, however, scientists discovered that the collision had produced a series of thin gashes as well as brittle fracturing and separation of seams in the adjacent hull plates, thus allowing water to flood into the Titanic. Later examination of retrieved ship parts—as well as paperwork in the builder’s archives—led to speculation that low-quality steel or weak rivets may have contributed to the sinking.****
